title: Will Poland reinstate visa-free travel for Kaliningrad before 2018?
preds: I doubt anything will happen in the next week.

You can get 72-hours visa only at 3 points:
Mamonovo-Branevo, Bagrationovsk or an airport*. 
*In a case of arrival by plane you should pay for the transport for the officier of the MFA to the airport. The price is €60.
The visa costs €70 per person The 72-hour visa is given to citizens of UK, Japan and Schengen countries (Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Sloveni, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Liechtenstein). This visa is valid only for Kaliningrad region.

Visa-Free Polish-Russian Border Traffic To Remain Suspended Warsaw Point (2017) March 27, states that: Visa-free local border traffic between Poland and Russia will not be restored anytime soon, the Gazeta Polska Codziennie daily has reported, pointing to military activities in the Kaliningrad enclave, The News reported. A visa-free border traffic agreement, which made travel between Russia and Poland easier for residents of the border area, was suspended last year ahead of a NATO summit in Warsaw and World Youth Day in Kraków, southern Poland. Gazeta Polska Codziennie quoted the Polish interior ministry’s Sebastian Chwałek as saying: “The negative events which have intensified recently include growing militarization of the Kaliningrad enclave and increased activity of Russian special services”. According to the daily, Russian media reported late last year that S-400 Triumf missile systems, which have a 400-km range and are able to seek out six targets at the same time, had been set up in the Kaliningrad enclave. The daily added that, in the case of an invasion, Russia would be able to stop NATO forces from assisting the Baltic states (para.1-5). Warsaw Point News Website. (2017). Visa-Free Polish-Russian Border Traffic To Remain Suspended. Warsaw Point. Politics. Retrieved from
http://warsawpoint.com/politics/2464-visa-free-polish-russian-border-traffic-remain-suspended.html

"Last autumn, the Polish interior minister rejected the repeal of the measure, although it was deeply unpopular among the population from the beginning. Many people living in the Polish border region have relatives and friends in Kaliningrad, and were able to travel repeatedly to the Russian enclave under the visa-free rules. The region also benefited economically from the visa-free border traffic, since many Russians came across the border to shop in Poland. Moreover, the province of Warmia-Masuria, like the rest of northeastern Poland, is the main focus of paramilitary, right-wing units, whose build-up Polish Defence Minister Antoni Macierewicz has systematically encouraged over the last year. In November, the Sejm (parliament) agreed the creation of a territorial defence unit (WOT), comprising 53,000 men and to be concentrated mostly in the northeast and southeast of the country. Paramilitary organizations belonging to the radical right were explicitly encouraged to join the WOT. Among the forces the PiS wants to integrate into the state apparatus as part of this is the fascist ONR, which has sought to exploit the violence in Ełk.
COMMENT: There are an incredible amount of resources online to explore this tense and fascinating topic. It is a sad irony of history that the city where Kant dreamed up of perpetual peace faces bleak prospects of attaining it, and much larger ones of igniting war. Poland has to explain the exact security concerns of a closing that it initially justified as temporary for the World Youth Day, or it could be questioned for seeking petty economic advantages (see http://www.thenews.pl/1/10/Artykul/267778,Kaliningrad-border-restrictions-%E2%80%98will-benefit-budget%E2%80%99-official) and a false sense of security, while sabotaging , for example, the 2018 World Cup.

Not so long as Königsberg remains Russian.

Due to the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, the Kaliningrad Oblast became an exclave, geographically separated from the rest of Russia. This isolation from the rest of Russia became even more pronounced politically when Poland and Lithuania became members of NATO and subsequently the European Union in 2004. All military and civilian land links between the region and the rest of Russia have to pass through members of NATO and the EU. Special travel arrangements for the territory's inhabitants have been made through the Facilitated Transit Document (FTD) and Facilitated Rail Transit Document (FRTD).
Since the early 1990s, the Kaliningrad oblast has been a Free Economic Zone (FEZ Yantar). In 1996, Kaliningrad was designated a Special Economic Zone, referred to as FEZ Yantar. Manufacturers based there get tax and customs duty breaks on the goods they send to other parts of Russia. Although corruption was an early deterrent, that policy means the region is now a manufacturing hub. One in three televisions in Russia is made in Kaliningrad (including Ericsson brand by Telebalt Ltd. and Polar by an eponymous firm located in the city of Chernyakhovsk) and it is home to Cadillac, Hummer and BMW related car plants (produced by Avtotor). Currently, Kaliningrad's major industries are manufacturing, shipping, fishing and amber products. In 2006, Moscow declared it would turn the region into "the Russian Hong Kong". The European Commission provides funds for business projects under its special programme for Kaliningrad. With an average GDP growth of more than 10% per year for three years to 2007, Kaliningrad grew faster than any other region in Russia, even outstripping the success of its EU neighbours. By early 2015, the BBC reported the region's trade with the countries of the EU was increasing, with improved economic growth and industrial output. Poland and the Russian Federation have an arrangement whereby residents of Kaliningrad and the Polish cities of Olsztyn, Elbląg and Gdańsk may obtain special cards permitting repeated travel between the two countries, crossing the Polish–Russian border. As of July 2013, Poland had issued 100,000 of the cards. That year, Russians visiting Poland to shop at the Biedronka and Lidl supermarkets featured in songs by musical group Parovoz. In 2004 Germany opened a consulate general in Kaliningrad. This consulate allows Kaliningrad residents to get Schengen visas without having to travel to Moscow. An agreement between Gerhard Schröder, Chancellor of Germany, and President of Russia Vladimir Putin established the consulate in light of Lithuania and Poland, which surround Kaliningrad, joining the EU. Russian concerns with Germany wanting the former Königsberg back had stifled earlier plans for a German consulate. In July 2007, Russian First Deputy Prime Minister Sergei Ivanov declared that if US-controlled missile defense systems were deployed in Poland, then nuclear weapons might be deployed in Kaliningrad. On November 5, 2008, Russian leader Dmitry Medvedev said that installing missiles in Kaliningrad was almost a certainty. These plans were suspended, however, in January 2009. But during late 2011, a long range Voronezh radar was commissioned to monitor missile launches within about 6,000 kilometres (3,728 miles). It is situated in the settlement of Pionersky (formerly German Neukuhren) in Kaliningrad Oblast.

Russia-NATO relations aren't so hot right now.  Poland and the other Eastern European countries are very uptight about Russia's recent aggressions, and will remain so even if Trump makes a U-turn. Kaliningrad is a closed Russian province and major military center, and Poland is hardly likely to want to have unrestricted travel from such an area, even if they are experiencing an upswing in the right-wing politics that Russia seems to be the center of.
It's not in the Polish agenda any visa free travel for Kaliningrad's citizens.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Although the removal of the visa-free agreement is depriving Poles around the Kaliningrad border of a stable income source, there likely won't be enough pressure on the government to make a change, especially since the next elections likely won't be until late 2019 and the majority of affected Poles aren't PiS voters anyways (they swing towards PO in the north of Poland). Additionally, reinstating the visa-free agreement would be a hugely symbolic move that would be in direct opposition with current Polish rhetoric about the Russian threat. On top of this, Russia is stationing Iskander missiles in Kaliningrad and the USA has begun to move its largest troop deployment since the Cold War into Poland. Tensions are high, and since most Eastern and Central European countries are anxious about Trump's commitment (or lack thereof) to Article 5, I don't see much room for rapprochement anytime soon.
Anti Russian attitude of Polish Govt.
If you were Poland and familiar with The Little Green Men of Ukraine, would you let Russians wander around your countryside?
Cut this one in half, the military maneuvers in Poland stating by month end are not going to be a conducive way to get this issue resolve by the end of the year.

Given the noises made by both Russia (about NATO troops in Poland) and Poland (about the risks from Russia's behavior), lifting the visa seems highly unlikely, especially as there is an alternative, not too onerous procedure (online visa application).

“The reasons for suspending local border traffic with Kaliningrad have not dissipated,” Deputy Interior Minister Jaroslaw Zielinski said in Szczytno, northern Poland, on Wednesday. “The decision is based on concern over Poland’s security in general. When we’re sure it’s safe, we’ll return to the issue.”

The conflict in Donbass (Eastern Ukraine) is far from being solved. A move to re-establish the visa-free travel (though probably having some economical benefits to Poland) is a political gesture  towards normalizing the relationship with Russia. Though, in a longer term (3 years +) it is entirely possible, in a short term it is highly unlikely.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Consensus seems about right here. Poland does get some benefit to the local economy along the border, and if the agreement was still in place would not rescind it. But reinstating it would give a positive message of trust to Russia, which doesn't sound like something the central government would want to give. The rest of the EU does not seem to have much of an opinion one way or another, so it is not likely to push Poland in any specific direction. If this was an election year the central govt might be under pressure to give a boost to the local economy, which would raise the probability quite a bit. But with no particular reason to favor the locals, the consensus estimate sounds right.

I am changing my mind on this. With international attention focused on Russia's attempts to influence elections in other countries, the Polish government would want to know who enters Poland from Kaliningrad. This would trump the economic benefit of having an increased cross-border flow. Besides, the current system of online visa applications (as I understand) is not too cumbersome and generally achieves the right balance between the two objectives. Keeping 1% just because the horizon is long - almost 1 year, and anything can happen.
Poland will continue to worry about polite green visitors.
Polen is one of the most russophobic countries since centuries, and as long as Papa allows the dog to bark, it will bark.
There is no idication, sign or trend reflecting this development.

Ukraine and Kaliningrad traffic was suspended for the Nato summit July, Ukraine reinstated August. Kaliningrad is an enclave and as such needs greater access to poland for the traffic of goods although this hasn't been stopped, just impeded. Economically the benefit to Poland of visa-free arrangements does not appear to be overwhelming. The EU historically was pro the arrangement though this may have changed given the sanctions subsequently in place over Ukraine. Overall it is a relatively small negotiating token probably of more benefit to the Russian citizens but also of some value to Poland. Lithuania should also be considered as the northern edge of the enclave. There are some cultural tensions between Poland and Lithuania which may also bring Kaliningrad as a political item though I cannot see if there is visa free travel between Lithuania and Kaliningrad although Lithuanian rhetoric appears to have been more strident. The choice not to reinstate visa-free travel followed a trajectory of declining relations with Russia. However, I would not write off the possibility entirely because there is no concrete reason to do so and it would be beneficial to both parties to reinstate the visa-free travel.

Bowing to the wisdom of the consensus (even though the sample is small), I lower my forecast down from 50%. Apparently the majority of forecasters believe the international politics argument will prevail over domestic economic and political considerations (e.g., to win some support in the border regions after the recent political tensions). Still, I'd keep my forecast well above consensus for now.

Poland is emphatically anti-Putin and Kaliningrad's governor answers to Russia, so I think there is absolutely zero possibility of the current government in Poland allowing open borders there for fear of becoming the next Ukraine -- eaten up by the Russian bear one mouthful at a time.
Here we have an interplay of international politics on the one hand, and domestic politics and economics on the other hand. Looks like either outcome is possible.

From: http://togroklife.com/category/poland/ A Pole walking along the road happens to spy a lamp. He picks it up, and as it is covered in rust he gives it quick rub. Out comes a genie. “I’m the genie of the lamp and I can grant you three wishes,” the genie says. “OK,” says the Pole. “I want the Chinese Army to invade Poland.” Odd choice, the genie thinks, but nevertheless he grants the wish, and the Chinese Army comes all the way from China, invades, and goes back home. “Right, second wish. Maybe something more positive,” says the genie. “No,” replies the Pole, “I want the Chinese Army to invade again.” So the Chinese come all the way from China, lay waste to more of Poland, and then go home. “Listen,” says the genie. “You have one last wish. I can make Poland the most beautiful and prosperous place on earth.” “If you don’t mind, I want the Chinese army to invade one more time.” So the Chinese army comes again, destroys what’s left of Poland, and then goes home for the last time. “I don’t understand,” says the genie. “Why did you want the Chinese army to invade Poland three times?” “Well,” replies the Pole, “they had to go through Russia six times.”

I think the bigger issue is not whether Poland will allow it again, but whether Russia will. Putin would have seen the suspension as a slight and therefore, in my opinion, would be very reluctant to allow this to happen again. I would like people's opinion on whether this needs both Poland and Russia to agree before it would count as a "yes".

While the border regions of Poland need the cross-border economy I am not sure that economic concerns will win over security issues. Clearly Poland is responding to Russia moving missiles into Kaliningrad.
Why should they? There is a 72hrs Kalingrad only online visa option, so I wonder why bother.

It is in the economic interest of Poland to resume the visa free accord.  While the current administration and most news sources have been negative on Russia it may be about to change.  Trump is going to look for cooperation and better relations and Putin will reciprocate.  Europe will have to accept the reality of the Ukraine situation.  Actually they will find lower tensions with Russia as having a beneficial side.

Not very many of Russia's adjoining neighbors trust Putin just now.  They may for example worry about fake freedom fighters infilrating as they did into Ukraine, even if that's not Putin's current plan.  Blandishments are possible, but it would need to be Pretty Good Stuff, and the deal would need to be quickly reversible as soon as it became clear that Russia has no intention of keeping up its end.  Stay tuned.

As of August 2016 visa-free access to Kaliningrad has been suspended indefinitely July 4, 2016.  Open source data indicate that the current status remains the same.  Additional data indicate that there is no visa exemptions with respect to its relationship with Poland.  No contradictory information has been found (based in varying on varying open source data).

Poland's regions bordering Kaliningrad will be in favor of re-opening. To defuse domestic tensions on other issues, the government in Warsaw may comply. On the other hand, evidence of Russia meddling in European elections may give them pause.
I suspect that there is a better than a "Even(50%)" chance that Poland will establish visa-free travel for Kaliningrad prior to 2 January 2018.
